questions.question: What are the three types of 'height' referred to in the Civil Aviation Rules Part 1?
What is the definition of 'height'?
questions.answer: The vertical distance of a level, a point, or an object considered as a point, measured from a specified datum and includes the vertical dimension of the object.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'altitude'?
questions.answer: The vertical distance of a level, a point, or an object considered as a point, measured from mean sea level.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'pressure altitude'?
questions.answer: An atmospheric pressure, expressed in terms of altitude, which corresponds to that pressure in the standard atmosphere.

questions.question: In simple terms, height is __________ and (is/is not) affected by atmospheric density.
questions.answer: The actual distance above a point, level, or object. Is not.

questions.question: In simple terms, altitude is __________ and (is/is not) affected by atmospheric density.
questions.answer: The distance above Mean Sea Level. Is.

questions.question: In simple terms, pressure altitude is __________. It is commonly referred to as __________ and is measured in __________.
questions.answer: The altitude shown on the altimeter when the subscale is set to 1013.2 hPa. Flight levels. Hundreds of feet.

questions.question: In New Zealand, flight levels are (almost always) used for flights __________, referred to as FL___
Altitude in an aircraft is typically measured with a __________ altimeter.
Describe the basic operation of a pressure altimeter.
questions.answer: The static port is connected to an expandable capsule. As the aircraft ascends, air density decreases and the capsule contracts. This is converted to a mechanical reading on the altimeter.

questions.question: The altimeter subscale allows the altimeter to be set to a __________.
What are the three types of altimeter settings in New Zealand?
QNH is __________. When set, the altimeter reads __________.
QNE is __________. When set, the altimeter reads __________.
questions.answer: ISA sea level pressure (1013.2 hPa). Flight levels.

questions.question: QFE is __________. When set, the altimeter reads __________.
questions.answer: Field elevation. Height above the selected datum (eg. aerodrome).

questions.question: You fly 2600' over a 3300' high mountain. Your height above the mountain is _____', your altitude is _____'.
QNH is based on the pressure at __________ and needs to be set at __________.
If you fly from an area of high pressure to an area of low pressure, your altimeter will read (higher/lower) than your actual altitude.
If you fly from an area of low pressure to an area of high pressure, your altimeter will read (higher/lower) than your actual altitude.
What are two important reasons for making sure you have the correct altimeter setting set?
questions.answer: Terrain clearance. Separation from other aircraft.

questions.question: A pressure change of 1 hPa = an altitude change of _____ feet.
You fly from an area with SLP of 1011 hPa to 1017 without adjusting your altimeter. Your altimeter reads 3000', what is your actual altitude?
Temperature (does/does not) affect indicated altitude.
How does a temperature warmer than ISA standard affect indicated altitude?
questions.answer: Altimeter reads lower than actual altitude, you are higher than indicated.

questions.question: How does a temperature colder than ISA standard affect indicated altitude?
questions.answer: Altimeter reads higher than actual altitude, you are lower than indicated.

questions.question: Flying from (high/low) pressure to (high/low) pressure without adjusting the altimeter setting will result in a descent.
What is calibrated altitude?
questions.answer: Indicated altitude corrected for non-standard pressure and temperature (ie. with the correct QNH set), adjusted for installation error.

questions.question: What are examples of altimeter installation error?
questions.answer: Incorrect pressure at the static vent. Wear on tubes. Mechanical wear.

questions.question: What does FIR stand for?
What is a QNH zone?
questions.answer: An area up to and including 13,000' and where QNH values are normally similar.

questions.question: How many QNH zones are there in New Zealand?
FL150 is known as the __________, and is the lowest _____ _____ available for _____ _____.
questions.answer: Transition level. Pressure altitude. Cruise flight.

questions.question: Airspace between 13,000' and 15,000' is known as the __________ and (is/is not) normally used for cruise flight..
When descending and passing FL150, the altimeter is set to _____.
When ascending and passing 13,000', the altimeter is set to _____.
VFR cruising altitudes apply above _____' _____, or _____' _____, whichever is higher.
What are the VFR cruising altitude rules in NZ?
questions.answer: 270° to 089°: Odd thousands of feet + 500'. 090° to 269°: Even thousands of feet + 500'.

questions.question: VFR cruising altitude rules are based on (true/magnetic) (track/heading).
